I keep waiting for others to ask this question, which tells me I have to be=

misinterpreting something....

You keep mentioning planetary movements and=
 astrological data. Are you
trying to predict the stock market based on the=
 movement of the planets? Why
on earth...;-)....do you think that's a causa=
l variable of predictive value?




Best regards,
Jeff Clune

>> Hi Pete=
r, 
>> 
>> I'd suggest that you try regular NEAT first, HyperNEAT may not b=
e neccessary.
>> HyperNEAT is a good choice if the inputs are hundreds or t=
housands in number
>> and/or there is some obvious geometry in the input sp=
ace that can be
>> exploited 
> 
>> by arranging the positions of the subst=
rate nodes. For financial applications
>> I'd use a small set of inputs, bu=
t very preprocessed data, like what most
>> good 
> 
>> custom indicators d=
o, and regular NEAT.
>> 
>> 
>> Peter
>> 
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, W=
esley Tansey <tansey@> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Peter,
>>> 
>>> I think you'd be bet=
ter off familiarizing yourself with the details of
>>> how HyperNEAT works.=
 Novelty Search is a different algorithm altogether,
>>> for a different cl=
ass of problems. You probably should familiarize
>>> yourself with the Hype=
rNEAT algorithm before trying to design an
>>> experiment. The HyperNEAT us=
er's page has a lot of really good
>>> information: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu=
/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
>>> 
>>> I'm not familiar with the EPlex's C+=
+ framework, but SharpNEAT does
>>> provide a GUI. However, it's more of an=
 engineer's GUI, designed to
>>> visualize your experiment after you set it=
 up in code. I tend to find it
>>> easier to just use SharpNEAT in a consol=
e application. I've written some
>>> tutorials on how to create a SharpNEAT=
 experiment:
>>> 
>>> http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolvin=
g-neural-networks-with-
>>> sharpneat-2-part-1/
>> /
>>> /
>>> 
>>> Hope th=
at helps.
>>> 
>>> Sincerely,
>>> Wesley
>>>
